name: Child and Family Team Meetings
description:
Child and Family Teams (CFTs) bring together loved ones and experts to support the child in reaching their potential and are dedicated to helping the family thrive.
- CFTs draw on a child and family’s strengths, experiences, knowledge, and network of support to create a plan for the safety, stability, and well-being of the children and family.
- The CFT process is intended to be inclusive of multiple formal support systems a family may need, as well as the informal, community, and natural supports that surround a family.
- The CFT process provides children and families opportunities to use their experiences and contribute their ideas to help them reach their goals.
Every child and family is unique, requiring support be tailored with them. The Chid and Family Team meets at regular intervals in a family's case with child welfare to include: 
- After the initial removal
- For each change of placement
- Prior to court hearings 
- At the request of any team member to address issues of placement and service planning
eligibility: Every youth involved with the child welfare system has a Child and Family Team.

name: Intesive Services Foster Care (ISFC) Family Only Support
description:
Allows for county use of the ISFC level payment on
an urgent, time-limited basis (up to 60 days) to any RF for
children/NMD with urgent placement needs, or to any RF on
an on-going basis, based on the intensive needs of the
child/NMD if they [the RF] meet a level of specified training
and competencies matched to the child’s needs at this level
and the rate is based on the Level of Care Protocol.
eligibility: Foster youth who have Intensive Services Foster Care (ISFC) needs.

name: Intesive Services Foster Care (ISFC)  Services Only Support
description:
The SO rate may be used by the county to secure services and supports from an FFA, Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP), Community Based Organization (CBO), Tribal service provider, or other appropriate public or private entity. This is to ensure that services continue to be provided for children/NMDs whose intensive needs make them eligible for ISFC program-level services and to stabilize their placement even if their RF is not affiliated with an ISFC program. There is no limitation on the length of time the SO rate may be used for a child/NMD. Counties also have flexibility to determine the amount of the SO rate they intend to use, which means the county may pay a portion of SO rate or the entire amount, as long as the county is satisfying its obligation to meet the needs of the child/NMD.

The SO rate is intended to be used flexibly based on the needs of the child/NMD and families to support permanency and/or placement stability efforts. Services provided through this rate should be documented in the child’s/NMD’s case plan. These funds could be used to pay for oversight and support of the RF until a new ISFC provider can be secured.
eligibility: Foster youth who have Intensive Services Foster Care (ISFC) needs, in a home-based placement not affiliated with a Foster Family Agency (FFA)
county_restrictions: a home-based placement not affiliated with a Foster Family Agency (FFA) The SO rate may be used by the

name: Static Rate
description: Static Criteria is a list of behaviors or conditions that have been present within the last 12 months and indicate the need to provide a higher level of care and/or supervision for a youth, prior to the use of the Level of Care Protocol, in order to secure a safe placement with an approved RF for a youth presenting with higher supervision needs and to support the RF with a temporary rate for the enhanced level of care and supervision.
eligibility:
The exhaustive list of chronic behavioral or medical indicators that permit the use of the Static rate include:
• Adjudicated violent offenders
• Significant property damage
• Sex offenders/perpetrators
• Aggressive and assaultive
• Animal Cruelty
• Commercial Sexual Exploitation of Children (CSEC)
• Contraction of pandemic viruses, such as COVID-19
• Eating Disorder
• Fire Setting
• Gang activity
• Habitual runaway
• Habitual truancy
• Medically Fragile
• SHCN
• Psychiatric Hospitalization(s)
• Severe mental health issues including suicidal ideation and/or self-harm
• Substance use/abuse

name: Respite
description:
Respite is a request by the youth's current Resource Family to have a break. Respite care allows for the youth to be placed with another caregiver for a short period of time – up to 14 days per month. These services are not provided for the purpose of routine, on-going child care. Respite is especially helpful when foster children have complex care needs. Respite care can enable the caregiver(s) to:
- Reduce stress by being able to run errands in a much more expedient fashion
- Reduce stress by allowing some “me” time or “down” time to re-energize
- Maintain their physical health by allowing regular visits with their own physician
- Maintain their mental/emotional health by taking time to attend support groups
A respite caregiver shall be an approved relative or nonrelative extended family member (NREFM), an approved Resource Family, or certified respite care provider.
eligibility: Each county provides its own Respite plan, eligibility criteria, and payment rates.

name: Peer Partners
description:
Over the past decade, as child welfare, probation, and behavioral health agencies and community service providers have worked towards authentically engaging the voices of children, youth, parents, and families, the integration of peer partners into child and family serving programs has emerged as a central value and practice of engagement.

There is growing evidence that peer partner programs are an essential strategy to promote engagement and increase reunification among families and children that are involved in the child welfare system. Outcomes from working with peer partners include: instilling hope, promoting self-advocacy, connecting families to services, and promoting an agency culture shift to one that engages authentically with families. 

Peer partners have four key functions: 
(1) to ensure clients are equal partners, if not leaders, in the development and implementation of their behaviorally-based service plans, case plans, and treatment plans; 
(2) to represent the needs and perspectives of their client to internal and external stakeholders and decision makers within the system of care; 
(3) to ensure that their client has access to a comprehensive array of prevention and support services that meet their individual needs and increase family engagement; and 
(4) to ensure that these services are family-centered; easily accessible; respectful of cultural, ethnic, and other community characteristics; and stigma free.
eligibility:
Counties can choose how to identify and provide peer supports. Peer partners could include partners for:
- Current foster youth
- Bio Parents
- Caregivers
county_restrictions: programs has emerged as a central value

name: (Emergency) Child Care Bridge
description: The Emergency Child Care Bridge Program (Bridge Program) aims to facilitate the immediate placement of children within the foster care system into a stable child care and development setting by helping relatives, parenting youth under the jurisdiction of the court, or foster/resource families obtain child care services upon placement.  It provides time-limited vouchers for child care and child care navigator services for families to assist with accessing long-term child care. There is also a Trauma-Informed Care (TIC) training and coaching component for child care providers to enhance their ability to provide nurturing and safe environments for children. These solutions are used at the time of placement and are meant to stabilize children in the best possible settings ensuring that caretakers have adequate support to balance their work and home lives.
eligibility: Families may receive a time-limited voucher to assist with child care costs for children in the foster care system birth through age 12, and for youth with exceptional needs up to age 21. A voucher may be issued for an initial six-months, and then renewed for an additional six months, or until the child is successfully transitioned into long-term, subsidized child care. Eligibility may be extended beyond 12 months if there is a compelling reason, at the discretion of the county.

name: Independent Living Program (ILP)/Independent Living Services (ILS)
description:
The Independent Living Program provides training, services, and benefits to assist current and former foster youth in achieving self-sufficiency prior to, and after leaving, the foster care system. In California, each county has the flexibility to design services to meet a wide range of individual needs and circumstances, and to coordinate services with other Federal and State agencies engaged in similar activities.

The ILP is designed to assist current and former foster youth achieve self-sufficiency.  Some of the services provided are:
Daily living skills
Money management
Decision making
Building self-esteem
Financial assistance with college or vocational schools
Educational Resources
Housing (Transitional Housing)
Employment
eligibility:
Youth are eligible for ILP services from age 16 to the day before their 21st birthday, provided one of the following criteria is met:
The youth was/is in foster care at any time from their 16th to their 19th birthday.
The youth was placed in out-of-home care by a tribe or tribal organization between their 16th and 19th birthdays.
The youth is a former dependent who entered into a kinship guardianship at any age and is receiving/received Kinship Guardianship Assistance Payments (Kin-GAP) between the ages of 16 and 18.
The youth is a former dependent who entered into a Non-Related Legal Guardianship (NRLG) after attaining age 8 and is receiving/received permanent placement services.
county_restrictions: the foster care system. In California

name: CDSS Provided TA (System of Care Strike Team)
description: The System of Care (SOC) Strike Team is a child specific working group, in which connects/conducts warm hand offs to assist with a path forward when youth are staying in non-licensed settings. This is offered in addition to other Technical Assistance calls and it includes key local and state members to ensure that all system partners join to meet the needs of individual youth in foster care. The team from the state is a consistent set of individuals from CDSS, the Departments of Developmental Services, Health Care Services, and Education, helping to identify and secure additional supports and services the county may not yet have considered or been able to identify. When the call is scheduled to discuss a Tribal youth, a representative from the CDSS Office of Tribal Affairs participates.
eligibility: No specific eligibility criteria
state_direction: Please email: SOCTACALLS@dss.ca.gov to access this resource

name: Catalyst Center
description: The Catalyst Center is a training and technical assistance organization operated under the leadership of the California Alliance of Child and Family Services that represents the interests of child and family serving professionals in California. The Catalyst Center is committed to strengthening connections between research, policy, and practice to inform and lead capacity building efforts across the State of California for providers in the fields of child and family services. Contracted by the California Department of Social Services (CDSS), the Catalyst Center offers an array of consultative services and supports for placing entities, providers, behavioral health, educational partners, tribes, and Child and Family Team members.
eligibility: No specific eligibility criteria

name: University of Davis Health TEAM
description: Provides case consultations to improve the quality of life and placement stability for youth with neurodevelopmental disorders and psychiatric comorbidity, including autism, ADHD, traumatic brain injury, PTSD, depression, and more. Services will include diagnostic clarification, medication and treatment  recommendations, resources, and strategies to stabilize the youth.
eligibility: Consultation for youth and families can be accessed by counties, Tribes, STRTPs, service providers, schools, regional centers or directly by families via referral to CDSS.
state_direction: Request a referral form and further information by emailing CCR@dss.ca.gov

name: Ascend Diagnostic and Support Services
description: Provides case consultations for youth with a dual diagnosis of developmental disability (e.g. Intellectual disability or autism) and trauma or other mental health challenges.  Services will be tailored to fit the needs of the youth and may include strengthening collaboration and teaming with system of care partners, individual coaching of family or team members to develop connection and trust with the youth and family and manage youth behaviors, strategies for modifying mental health interventions to meet the needs of youth with developmental disabilities and trauma, strategies to preserve placement or assist with transitioning the youth, and other resources.
eligibility: Consultations can be accessed by providers including STRTPS, FFAs, regional centers, counties, or directly by families via referral to CDSS.
state_direction:
Request a referral form and further information by
emailing CCR@dss.ca.gov

name: General State Technical Assistance
eligibility: No specific eligibility criteria.
state_direction: If a county would benefit from a technical assistance call, please contact, SOCTACALLS@dss.ca.gov

name: Family Urgent Response System (FURS)
description:
The Family Urgent Response System (FURS) is a coordinated statewide, regional, and county-level system designed to provide collaborative and timely state-level phone-based response and county-level in-home, in-person mobile response during situations of instability, to preserve the relationship of the caregiver and the child or youth.
FURS Services Include:
- A toll-free hotline available 24 hours a day, 7 days a week staffed with caring counselors trained in conflict resolution and de-escalation techniques for children and youth impacted by trauma.
- County Mobile Response and Stabilization Teams also available 24 hours a day, 7 days a week.
- In-home de-escalation, stabilization, conflict resolution, and support services and resources.
- Ongoing support services beyond the initial mobile response.
- Hotline and mobile response staff trained in working with children and families who have experienced trauma.
eligibility: Current and former foster youth and their caregivers can call the FURS hotline for support.

name: Resource Family (Relative and Non-Relative)
description: An individual or family approved by child welfare under the Resource Family Approval (RFA) program to provide care for a child/youth or NMD who is under the jurisdiction of Juvenile Court under a WIC 300 or 600 petition. Families approved under RFA consist of relatives/NREFMs and non-relatives. RFs are home-based placements who can take children with varying demographics (age, gender, etc) and needs based on their preferences and approval status. RFs may be trained and approved by Child Welfare, Probation, and Foster Family Agencies; the approving entity is also the entity that monitors the RF home.
eligibility:
Youth may be placed in a RF home when the youth's needs can be safely met by the caregiver, placing agency, and Child and Family Team - including both natural and formal supports. 

Youth may be placed with a relative/NREFM prior to full RFA if the home meets emergency placement criteria, including an assessment of 361.3/361.4 factors.
state_direction:
ACL 16-10
WIC 16519.5
RFA Written Directives v8.0

name: Tribally Approved Home (TAH)
description: A home that has met the federal requirements for background checks and a home health and safety assessment, as assessed by the tribe's/tribal agency's socially and cutlurally approporaite standards. The TAH must be approved by the specific child's tribe.
eligibility: Indian children who are receiving placement approval from their specific tribe. If a sibling set with a non-Indian child needs home-based placement, the home must be RFA approved, the non-Indian child cannot be placed in a TAH.

Indian Child Welfare Act (ICWA)

name:
Interstate Compact for the Placement of Children (ICPC) 
AKA Out of State Placement - non-congregate care
description:
Placement of youth with a relative/NREFM who has been approved by the caregiver's state of residence. The Interstate Compact on the Placement of Children (ICPC) establishes legal and administrative procedures for the interstate placement of children.
The ICPC is a contract among all 50 states, the District of Columbia, and the U.S. Virgin Islands authorizing them to work together to ensure that children who are placed across state lines for foster care or adoption receive adequate protection and support. Interstate placement requests for relative homes, foster family homes and prospective adoptive homes are processed by counties and licensed adoption agencies.
eligibility:
Any youth in out of home care can be considered for an ICPC home based placement when a relative/NREFM is identified and approved by the state in which they reside. 
Child Welfare cannot place youth in congregate care outside of California.

name: ISFC
description: Sometimes children may require more intensive structured care. Intensive Services Foster Care (ISFC) provides more intensive care within a Resource Family. ISFC Resource Families receive additional training and support in order to provide more intensive care to children who may have complex mental health, behavioral, or medical needs.The program requires specially trained resource parents and professional and paraprofessional support. The ISFC program provides core services and supports to a child/youth in foster care. These core services may include, but are not limited to arranging access to mental health treatment, providing trauma informed care and providing transitional support from foster placement to permanent home placement.The goal is to ensure that the services needed are provided in a home-based family care setting or to prevent placement into, or assistance stepping down from, a Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP). Along with additional services and supports, the caregiver is paid the highest home-based foster care rate available.
eligibility:
An eligible child for ISFC is a child or nonminor dependent in foster
care who requires a higher level of care of supervision as determined by the Level of
Care Rate Determination Protocol (LOCP) - youth who score a five in either the Health or Behavioral Domains of the LOCP qualify for ISFC. The placing agency's Interagency Placement Committee can also approve a youth for ISFC.

name: Home Based IMC (EISFC or ISFC+)
description:
A program-specific or a child-specific rate for a county-designed Innovative Model of Care (IMC) providing an innovative program or model of care and services to support foster children and Non-Minor Dependents (NMDs) with complex needs unable to be met in existing Aid to Families with Dependent Children-Foster Care (AFDC-FC) programs or using alternative funding sources. For youth who have enhanced care, supervision, and service needs, not met by any other available placement/program, as a way to divert from residential care. Home-based IMC, sometimes called Enhanced ISFC (EISFC) or ISFC+, can be created as an individual model for the resource parent home (known as a professional parent model), or as an individual model per youth who needs placement. IMC gives counties and caregivers ability to be innovative in creating a set of services and supports tailored to the complex care youth. The plan is negotiated between the county and the potential caregiver. The IMC Rate is created in partnership with County or Tribe, the potential placement, and the CDSS Rate’s Oversight Unit based on the  needs and supports  being provided by the potential placement.

IMC could encompass innovative models across counties, including Two Family Homes, programs that utilize old MTFC/ITFC principles and programming, and partnerships with behavioral health, respite, and other providers.
eligibility:
Youth with complex care needs can be assessed for an IMC placement.
Caregivers who are able and willing to meet the needs of complex care youth, may apply to be an IMC home. 
Both child specific, and home/facility based IMC, require approval from CDSS.

name: Congregate Care IMC (STRTP of One or Two
description:
A program-specific or a child-specific rate for a county-designed Innovative Model of Care (IMC) providing an innovative program or model of care and services to support foster children and Non-Minor Dependents (NMDs) with complex needs unable to be met in existing Aid to Families with Dependent Children-Foster Care (AFDC-FC) programs or using alternative funding sources. Congregate care IMC can provide care and services for a child or NMD in foster care with complex needs who would not otherwise be successful if placed in an STRTP congregate care setting.  Congregate care based IMC, sometimes called an STRTP of One or STRTP of Two, can be created as a program model, or as an individual model per youth who needs placement. This IMC should seek to provide an innovative approach using, in new and original ways, intensive child-to-staff ratios, multi-systemic involvement, intensive clinical supports, intensive care coordination that is focused on a timely transition to a less restrictive setting, and utilize trauma-informed models, including intensive home-based services, wraparound services, and after care supports.
An STRTP of One or Two must comply with all the licensing and child welfare requirements that apply to all STRTPs. While an STRTP of One IMC may be either program-specific or child-specific, an STRTP of Two IMC is likely to be program-specific.  The IMC Rate is created in partnership with County or Tribe, the potential placement, and the CDSS Rate’s Oversight Unit based on the  needs and supports  being provided by the potential placement.
eligibility:
Youth with complex care needs can be assessed for an IMC placement.
Caregivers who are able and willing to meet the needs of complex care youth, may apply to be an IMC home. 
Both child specific, and home/facility based IMC, require approval from CDSS.

name: STRTP
description:
An STRTP provides short-term intensive care and supervision, services and supports, treatment, and 24-hour care and supervision of children/youth and NMDs in a congregate care setting. 

An STRTP is intended to serve children/youth and NMDs who need a level of care and supervision that cannot be safely met in a family-based setting and who are not in need of inpatient services.
eligibility:
Youth with complex care needs not able to be met safely in a home-based placement, must have assessment and approval by the following three in order to be in an STRTP placement:
- Interagency Placement Committee (IPC)
- Qualified Individual (QI)
- Juvenile Court

To qualify for placement in an STRTP, the youth must meet all of Criteria One and at least one of Criteria Two as authorized by the IPC screening, as follows:

Criteria One (1):
- Inpatient care in a licensed health care facility is not required, and
- A determination has been made in conjunction with the Child and Family Team which indicates that the child/youth/NMD requires the level of services provided by an STRTP.

Criteria Two (2):
- The child/youth/NMD meets the medical necessity criteria for Medi-Cal Specialty Mental Health Services as provided by an STRTP, or
- The child/youth/NMD is assessed as Seriously Emotionally Disturbed, or
- A licensed mental health professional assessed the youth as requiring the level of services provided in an STRTP in order to meet the youth’s behavioral or therapeutic needs
partners_involved:
CWS
Probation
Regional Center
Behavioral Health

STRTP Interim Licensing Standards v5
ACL 21-114

name: CTF
description: Community Treatment Facility (CTF):  A CTF provides 24-hour non-medical care and mental health treatment services to children in a secure environment, which are less restrictive than a hospital.  A facility's program design is subject to program standards developed and enforced by the State Department of Health Care Services (DHCS).
eligibility:
Youth with complex care needs not able to be met safely in a home-based placement or lower levels of congregate care, must have assessment and approval by the following three in order to be in an STRTP placement:
- Interagency Placement Committee (IPC)
- Qualified Individual (QI)
- Juvenile Court 
- Conservator (as applicable)

For the IPC screening to determine the appropriateness of treatment and placement in a CTF, the youth must be determined by a mental health care professional to be described as stated below:

The child/youth/NMD must meet one (1) or more of 1 a, or b, or c and items 2, 3, and 4 below.

1) The child/youth/NMD must have met the Seriously Emotionally Disturbed (SED) criteria as defined below.
a) Impairment in at least two (2) of the following areas: 
Self-Care
School Functioning
Family Relationships
Functioning in the community And either,
Risk of removal from home or has already been removed, or
The mental health disorder and impairments have been present for more than six (6) months, or are likely to continue for more than one (1) year without treatment.
b) The child/youth/NMD displays one (1) of the following:
Psychotic features
Risk of suicide
Risk of violence to other due to mental health disorder
c) The youth is a special education student that is determined to have an emotional disturbance.  This means a condition exhibiting one (1) or more of the following characteristics over a long period of time and to a degree that adversely affects a child's educational performance: 
An inability to learn that cannot be explained by intellectual, sensory, or health factors
An inability to build or maintain satisfactory interpersonal relationships with peers and teachers
Inappropriate types of behaviors or feelings under normal circumstances
A general pervasive mood of unhappiness or depression
A tendency to develop physical symptoms or fears associated with personal or school problems.
2) The youth may require a period of containment to participate in, and benefit from, mental health treatment, and the CTF program must be reasonably expected to improve the youth's mental health disorder.
3) Other, less restrictive interventions must have been attempted and proved insufficient; or, the youth is in an inpatient psychiatric hospital. This applies to youth's placed in and out of state.
This includes denial of admission into an STRTP through an IPC screening where it is determined the youth would benefit from a higher level of care.
This may include outpatient therapy, family counseling, case management, family preservation efforts, special education classes, or nonpublic schooling.
4) There must be consent for treatment/placement (by youth over age 18) or the youth must have a conservator appointed

name: CCCPP
description:
The Children’s Crisis Continuum Pilot Program (CCCPP) provided funding for a select number of counties or regional collaboratives throughout California to implement a crisis continuum of care for foster youth with high acuity needs. The purpose of the Children’s Crisis Continuum is to fully integrate the system of care for foster youth enabling a seamless transition between service settings and to provide stabilization and treatment to foster youth with high acuity needs within the least restrictive setting possible. The program will have access to ISFC beds specifically selected at partnering FFAs to support youth with high level mental health or substance use disorder needs. Pilot youth may require a combination of highly individualized stabilization services, inpatient treatment, or intensive transition planning and aftercare services. 

Pilot funding can be used to support activities including but not limited to:
-Investment in infrastructure and start up behavioral health services and placements for foster youth including Intensive Services Foster Care (ISFC) homes, Children’s Crisis Residential Programs, (CCRPs), Crisis Stabilization Units (CSUs), and Psychiatric Health Facilities (PHFs).
- Specialized services and supports for foster youth such as child-specific recruitment, intensive family finding and engagement, respite care, and additional therapeutic foster care options.
eligibility:
Counties awarded a CCCPP grant:
- Fresno & Madera Counties
- Los Angeles County
- Monterey County
- Riverside & San Bernardino Counties
- San Diego County
- San Francisco, Contra Costa, Marin, Solano, and
Sonoma Counties
- San Luis Obispo County
- Stanislaus, Merced, and San Joaquin Counties

Counties select their own specific eligibility criteria as reviewed and accepted by CDSS at the time of grant awarding.

name: TSCF
description: A Temporary Shelter Care Facility (TSCF) that provides no more than 10 calendar days of residential care and supervision for children pending long-term placement. TSCFs should be utilized for temporary care only after all available placement options have been exhausted.
eligibility:
TSCFs are available in the following counties:
- Imperial
- Kern
- Orange
- Sacramento
- San Diego
- San Joaquin
- Sonoma
- Los Angeles

name: Transitioal Housing Program (THP) - NMD
description:
A placement program available to NMDs ages 18 up to 21. Offered by a licensed transitional housing placement provider (THPP) to provide safe housing for NMDs and assistance in developing the skills needed for transitioning to independent living with assistance from a case manager. 

The Transitional Housing Program (THP)-NMD provides current and former foster youth additional supports they need to successfully transition to independence while reducing the risks of homelessness, unemployment, and instability after foster care. By providing housing, life skills training, and guidance, the program helps Nonminor Dependents build a strong foundation for independent living and self-sufficiency. 

THP-NMD provides three types of supervised housing:
Single-Site Housing – Apartments or dorm-style housing where multiple NMDs live in the same building with onsite support staff.
Scattered-Site Housing – Individual apartments or shared housing located throughout the community, with regular case management visits.
Host Family Model – NMDs live with a caring adult mentor (host family) who provides support and guidance while maintaining independence.
eligibility:
To qualify for THP-NMD, youth must:
Be between 18 and 21 years old
Be in Extended Foster Care (EFC) under a court-ordered placement
Have a Transitional Independent Living Plan (TILP)
Be engaged in school, work, training, or treatment
Be willing to participate in program activities and case management.

name: FFA
description: A Foster Family Agency (FFA) is a public agency or private organization, organized and operated on a nonprofit basis. FFAs recruit, approve, provide training for, and provide support and services to Resource Families.  FFAs coordinate with county placing agencies to find homes for dependent children in need of care. All homes within an FFA must be RFA approved. Youth may be placed in an FFA RFA home if they can safely be maintained at a home-based level of care, just as in county-based RF homes. FFAs could have standard RFA home, or could have treatment homes that run ISFC and/or TFC programs for higher needs youth.
eligibility: Youth may be placed in a RF home when the youth's needs can be safely met by the caregiver, placing agency, and Child and Family Team - including both natural and formal supports.
county_restrictions: a RF home when the youth's needs can be safely met by the caregiver

operated on a nonprofit basis. FFAs recruit
services to Resource Families.  FFAs coordinate with

name: Group Home
description:
Historical Background: Group homes provided the most restrictive out-of-home placement option for children in foster care. They provided a placement option for children with significant emotional or behavioral problems who require more restrictive environments. The licensed group home is defined as a facility of any capacity which provide 24-hour nonmedical care and supervision to children in a structured environment, with such services provided at least in part by staff employed by the licensee. Group homes run the gamut from large institutional type environments which provide an intense therapeutic setting, often called "residential treatment centers," to small home environments which incorporate a "house parent" model. As a result, group home placements provide various levels of structure, supervision and services.
Group homes may offer specific services targeted to a specific population of children or a range of services depending on the design of their program. These services include substance abuse, minor-parent (mothers and babies), infant programs, mental health treatment, vocational training, mental health day treatment, sex offenders, wards only, emancipation and reunification. Many programs provide more than one service and list their primary service function as reunification of children with the biological family. A high number also list their primary function as emancipation.
eligibility: Per WIC 17736(b), group homes are generally no longer allowable as a placement for children/youth in foster care, with the exception of licensed group homes that have been vendorized by a Regional Center to serve Regional Center clients.

name: Small Family Home (Non-Vendorized)
description:
A Small Family Home (SFH) is a for-profit licensed facility that provides 24-hour care for six or fewer children, often those with disabilities, requiring special care and supervision. Staff in the home may include the operator of the home, assistant caregivers, on-call assistants, and other providers. For SFH's not vendorized by Regional Center, Child Welfare must negotiate the services provided and rate paid for each placement. Services in a SFH may include:
Child activities
Participating with agencies and other responsible persons in planning for and providing the needs of the child.
Ensuring that the child is clean and providing the child with training in personal cleanliness and hygiene.
Protecting the child from home accidents.
Making provisions for the child to attend available community treatment or training programs when the child has needs which can be met by such programs.
Assisting the child in the development of goals and encouraging them to reach those goals.
Supervising the provision of basic services within the home.
Unless restricted by the case plan adopted by the court or other court order,  permit and facilitate connections between the child and the child’s family and non-relative extended family members. 
Provide access and information reagrding vocational and other postsecondary educational options.
eligibility: Small Family Homes are generally no longer allowable as a placement for children/youth in foster care, with the exception of licensed SFHs that have been vendorized by a Regional Center to serve Regional Center clients.

name: Supervised Independent Living Placement (SILP)
description: A SILP is a placement option for NMDs who are in Extended Foster Care (EFC). The SILP is intended to provide young adults with the opportunity for highly independent living experiences while receiving financial support along with the safety net of a SW to provide support and services for problems that arise. A SILP may be with parent or guardian from whom the youth was removed .
eligibility:
NMDs, including married NMDs, are responsible for finding their own SILP; however, the SILP must still be approved by the SW.

NMDs receiving a Dual Agency Rate are not appropriate for a SILP.

name: High Fidelity Wrap
eligibility:
Required for youth stepping down from an STRTP to a home-based placement for six months.

The service can only be provided by a certified provider.
state_direction:
Updated ACL pending
CA Wraparound Standards (WIC 4096.6)
ACIN I-52-25
ACL 18-81
ACL/BHIN 21-116/21-061

name: Child and Family Team Meetings
description:
Child and Family Teams (CFTs) bring together loved ones and experts to support the child in reaching their potential and are dedicated to helping the family thrive.
- CFTs draw on a child and family’s strengths, experiences, knowledge, and network of support to create a plan for the safety, stability, and well-being of the children and family.
- The CFT process is intended to be inclusive of multiple formal support systems a family may need, as well as the informal, community, and natural supports that surround a family.
- The CFT process provides children and families opportunities to use their experiences and contribute their ideas to help them reach their goals.
Every child and family is unique, requiring support be tailored with them. The Chid and Family Team meets at regular intervals in a family's case with Probation to include: 
- After the initial removal
- For each change of placement
- Prior to court hearings 
- At the request of any team member to address issues of placement and service planning
eligibility: Every youth involved with the child welfare system Probation that has a foster care order has a Child and Family Team.

name: Intesive Services Foster Care (ISFC) Family Only Support
description:
Allows for county use of the ISFC level payment on
an urgent, time-limited basis (up to 60 days) to any RF for
children/NMD with urgent placement needs, or to any RF on
an on-going basis, based on the intensive needs of the
child/NMD if they [the RF] meet a level of specified training
and competencies matched to the child’s needs at this level
and the rate is based on the Level of Care Protocol.
eligibility: Foster youth who have Intensive Services Foster Care (ISFC) needs.

name: Intesive Services Foster Care (ISFC)  Services Only Support
description:
The SO rate may be used by the county to secure services and supports from an FFA, Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP), Community Based Organization (CBO), Tribal service provider, or other appropriate public or private entity. This is to ensure that services continue to be provided for children/NMDs whose intensive needs make them eligible for ISFC program-level services and to stabilize their placement even if their RF is not affiliated with an ISFC program. There is no limitation on the length of time the SO rate may be used for a child/NMD. Counties also have flexibility to determine the amount of the SO rate they intend to use, which means the county may pay a portion of SO rate or the entire amount, as long as the county is satisfying its obligation to meet the needs of the child/NMD.

The SO rate is intended to be used flexibly based on the needs of the child/NMD and families to support permanency and/or placement stability efforts. Services provided through this rate should be documented in the child’s/NMD’s case plan. These funds could be used to pay for oversight and support of the RF until a new ISFC provider can be secured.
eligibility: Foster youth who have Intensive Services Foster Care (ISFC) needs, in a home-based placement not affiliated with a Foster Family Agency (FFA)
county_restrictions: a home-based placement not affiliated with a Foster Family Agency (FFA) The SO rate may be used by the

name: Static Rate
description: Static Criteria is a list of behaviors or conditions that have been present within the last 12 months and indicate the need to provide a higher level of care and/or supervision for a youth, prior to the use of the Level of Care Protocol, in order to secure a safe placement with an approved RF for a youth presenting with higher supervision needs and to support the RF with a temporary rate for the enhanced level of care and supervision.
eligibility:
The exhaustive list of chronic behavioral or medical indicators that permit the use of the Static rate include:
• Adjudicated violent offenders
• Significant property damage
• Sex offenders/perpetrators
• Aggressive and assaultive
• Animal Cruelty
• Commercial Sexual Exploitation of Children (CSEC)
• Contraction of pandemic viruses, such as COVID-19
• Eating Disorder
• Fire Setting
• Gang activity
• Habitual runaway
• Habitual truancy
• Medically Fragile
• SHCN
• Psychiatric Hospitalization(s)
• Severe mental health issues including suicidal ideation and/or self-harm
• Substance use/abuse

name: Respite
description:
Respite is a request by the youth's current Resource Family to have a break. Respite care allows for the youth to be placed with another caregiver for a short period of time – up to 14 days per month. These services are not provided for the purpose of routine, on-going child care. Respite is especially helpful when foster children have complex care needs. Respite care can enable the caregiver(s) to:
- Reduce stress by being able to run errands in a much more expedient fashion
- Reduce stress by allowing some “me” time or “down” time to re-energize
- Maintain their physical health by allowing regular visits with their own physician
- Maintain their mental/emotional health by taking time to attend support groups
A respite caregiver shall be an approved relative or nonrelative extended family member (NREFM), an approved Resource Family, or certified respite care provider.
eligibility: Each county provides its own Respite plan, eligibility criteria, and payment rates.

name: Peer Partners
description:
Over the past decade, as child welfare, probation, and behavioral health agencies and community service providers have worked towards authentically engaging the voices of children, youth, parents, and families, the integration of peer partners into child and family serving programs has emerged as a central value and practice of engagement.

There is growing evidence that peer partner programs are an essential strategy to promote engagement and increase reunification among families and children that are involved in the child welfare system. Outcomes from working with peer partners include: instilling hope, promoting self-advocacy, connecting families to services, and promoting an agency culture shift to one that engages authentically with families. 

Peer partners have four key functions: 
(1) to ensure clients are equal partners, if not leaders, in the development and implementation of their behaviorally-based service plans, case plans, and treatment plans; 
(2) to represent the needs and perspectives of their client to internal and external stakeholders and decision makers within the system of care; 
(3) to ensure that their client has access to a comprehensive array of prevention and support services that meet their individual needs and increase family engagement; and 
(4) to ensure that these services are family-centered; easily accessible; respectful of cultural, ethnic, and other community characteristics; and stigma free.
eligibility:
Counties can choose how to identify and provide peer supports. Peer partners could include partners for:
- Current foster youth
- Bio Parents
- Caregivers
county_restrictions: programs has emerged as a central value

name: (Emergency) Child Care Bridge
description: The Emergency Child Care Bridge Program (Bridge Program) aims to facilitate the immediate placement of children within the foster care system into a stable child care and development setting by helping relatives, parenting youth under the jurisdiction of the court, or foster/resource families obtain child care services upon placement.  It provides time-limited vouchers for child care and child care navigator services for families to assist with accessing long-term child care. There is also a Trauma-Informed Care (TIC) training and coaching component for child care providers to enhance their ability to provide nurturing and safe environments for children. These solutions are used at the time of placement and are meant to stabilize children in the best possible settings ensuring that caretakers have adequate support to balance their work and home lives.
eligibility: Families may receive a time-limited voucher to assist with child care costs for children in the foster care system birth through age 12, and for youth with exceptional needs up to age 21. A voucher may be issued for an initial six-months, and then renewed for an additional six months, or until the child is successfully transitioned into long-term, subsidized child care. Eligibility may be extended beyond 12 months if there is a compelling reason, at the discretion of the county.

and for youth with exceptional needs up to age 21. A voucher may be issued for an initial six-months
and then renewed for an additional six months
or until the child is successfully transitioned into long-term
subsidized child care. Eligibility may be extended beyond 12 months if there is a compelling reason

name: Independent Living Program (ILP)/Independent Living Services (ILS)
description:
The Independent Living Program provides training, services, and benefits to assist current and former foster youth in achieving self-sufficiency prior to, and after leaving, the foster care system. In California, each county has the flexibility to design services to meet a wide range of individual needs and circumstances, and to coordinate services with other Federal and State agencies engaged in similar activities.

The ILP is designed to assist current and former foster youth achieve self-sufficiency.  Some of the services provided are:
Daily living skills
Money management
Decision making
Building self-esteem
Financial assistance with college or vocational schools
Educational Resources
Housing (Transitional Housing)
Employment
eligibility:
Youth are eligible for ILP services from age 16 to the day before their 21st birthday, provided one of the following criteria is met:
The youth was/is in foster care at any time from their 16th to their 19th birthday.
The youth was placed in out-of-home care by a tribe or tribal organization between their 16th and 19th birthdays.
The youth is a former dependent who entered into a kinship guardianship at any age and is receiving/received Kinship Guardianship Assistance Payments (Kin-GAP) between the ages of 16 and 18.
The youth is a former dependent who entered into a Non-Related Legal Guardianship (NRLG) after attaining age 8 and is receiving/received permanent placement services.
county_restrictions: the foster care system. In California

name: CDSS Provided TA (System of Care Strike Team)
description: The System of Care (SOC) Strike Team is a child specific working group, in which connects/conducts warm hand offs to assist with a path forward when youth are staying in non-licensed settings. This is offered in addition to other Technical Assistance calls and it includes key local and state members to ensure that all system partners join to meet the needs of individual youth in foster care. The team from the state is a consistent set of individuals from CDSS, the Departments of Developmental Services, Health Care Services, and Education, helping to identify and secure additional supports and services the county may not yet have considered or been able to identify. When the call is scheduled to discuss a Tribal youth, a representative from the CDSS Office of Tribal Affairs participates.
eligibility: No specific eligibility criteria
state_direction: Please email: SOCTACALLS@dss.ca.gov to access this resource
county_restrictions: which connects/conducts warm hand offs to assist with a path forward when youth are staying in non-licensed settings. This is offered in addition to other Technical Assistance calls
state members to ensure that all system partners join to meet the needs of individual youth in foster care. The team from the state is a consistent set of individuals from CDSS

name: Catalyst Center
description: The Catalyst Center is a training and technical assistance organization operated under the leadership of the California Alliance of Child and Family Services that represents the interests of child and family serving professionals in California. The Catalyst Center is committed to strengthening connections between research, policy, and practice to inform and lead capacity building efforts across the State of California for providers in the fields of child and family services. Contracted by the California Department of Social Services (CDSS), the Catalyst Center offers an array of consultative services and supports for placing entities, providers, behavioral health, educational partners, tribes, and Child and Family Team members.
eligibility: No specific eligibility criteria
state_direction:
To inquire about the Children’s Services Foundation’s
services please contact the System of Care Technical
Assistance at SOCTACALLS@dss.ca.gov.

name: University of Davis Health TEAM
description: Provides case consultations to improve the quality of life and placement stability for youth with neurodevelopmental disorders and psychiatric comorbidity, including autism, ADHD, traumatic brain injury, PTSD, depression, and more. Services will include diagnostic clarification, medication and treatment  recommendations, resources, and strategies to stabilize the youth.
eligibility: Consultation for youth and families can be accessed by counties, Tribes, STRTPs, service providers, schools, regional centers or directly by families via referral to CDSS.
state_direction: Request a referral form and further information by emailing CCR@dss.ca.gov

name: Ascend Diagnostic and Support Services
description: Provides case consultations for youth with a dual diagnosis of developmental disability (e.g. Intellectual disability or autism) and trauma or other mental health challenges.  Services will be tailored to fit the needs of the youth and may include strengthening collaboration and teaming with system of care partners, individual coaching of family or team members to develop connection and trust with the youth and family and manage youth behaviors, strategies for modifying mental health interventions to meet the needs of youth with developmental disabilities and trauma, strategies to preserve placement or assist with transitioning the youth, and other resources.
eligibility: Consultations can be accessed by providers including STRTPS, FFAs, regional centers, counties, or directly by families via referral to CDSS.
state_direction:
Request a referral form and further information by
emailing CCR@dss.ca.gov

name: General State Technical Assistance
eligibility: No specific eligibility criteria.
state_direction: If a county would benefit from a technical assistance call, please contact, SOCTACALLS@dss.ca.gov

name: Family Urgent Response System (FURS)
description:
The Family Urgent Response System (FURS) is a coordinated statewide, regional, and county-level system designed to provide collaborative and timely state-level phone-based response and county-level in-home, in-person mobile response during situations of instability, to preserve the relationship of the caregiver and the child or youth.
FURS Services Include:
- A toll-free hotline available 24 hours a day, 7 days a week staffed with caring counselors trained in conflict resolution and de-escalation techniques for children and youth impacted by trauma.
- County Mobile Response and Stabilization Teams also available 24 hours a day, 7 days a week.
- In-home de-escalation, stabilization, conflict resolution, and support services and resources.
- Ongoing support services beyond the initial mobile response.
- Hotline and mobile response staff trained in working with children and families who have experienced trauma.
eligibility: Current and former foster youth and their caregivers can call the FURS hotline for support.

name: Resource Family (Relative and Non-Relative)
description: An individual or family approved by child welfare under the Resource Family Approval (RFA) program to provide care for a child/youth or NMD who is under the jurisdiction of Juvenile Court under a WIC 300 or 600 petition. Families approved under RFA consist of relatives/NREFMs and non-relatives. RFs are home-based placements who can take children with varying demographics (age, gender, etc) and needs based on their preferences and approval status. RFs may be trained and approved by Child Welfare, Probation, and Foster Family Agencies; the approving entity is also the entity that monitors the RF home.
eligibility:
Youth may be placed in a RF home when the youth's needs can be safely met by the caregiver, placing agency, and Child and Family Team - including both natural and formal supports. 

Youth may be placed with a relative/NREFM prior to full RFA if the home meets emergency placement criteria, including an assessment of 361.3/361.4 727.05 WIC factors.
state_direction:
ACL 16-10
WIC 16519.5
RFA Written Directives v8.0
WIC 361.3 and 361.4 WIC 727.05

name: Tribally Approved Home (TAH)
description: A home that has met the federal requirements for background checks and a home health and safety assessment, as assessed by the tribe's/tribal agency's socially and cutlurally approporaite standards. The TAH must be approved by the specific child's tribe.
eligibility: Indian children who are receiving placement approval from their specific tribe. If a sibling set with a non-Indian child needs home-based placement, the home must be RFA approved, the non-Indian child cannot be placed in a TAH.
state_direction:
ACL 19-71
Indian Child Welfare Act (ICWA)
(25 U.S.C. 1915).

name:
Interstate Compact for the Placement of Children (ICPC) 
AKA Out of State Placement - non-congregate care
description:
Placement of youth with a relative/NREFM who has been approved by the caregiver's state of residence. The Interstate Compact on the Placement of Children (ICPC) establishes legal and administrative procedures for the interstate placement of children.
The ICPC is a contract among all 50 states, the District of Columbia, and the U.S. Virgin Islands authorizing them to work together to ensure that children who are placed across state lines for foster care or adoption receive adequate protection and support. Interstate placement requests for relative homes, foster family homes and prospective adoptive homes are processed by counties and licensed adoption agencies.
eligibility:
Any youth in out of home care can be considered for an ICPC home based placement when a relative/NREFM is identified and approved by the state in which they reside. 
Child Welfare Probation cannot place youth in congregate care outside of California.

name: ISFC
description: Sometimes children may require more intensive structured care. Intensive Services Foster Care (ISFC) provides more intensive care within a Resource Family. ISFC Resource Families receive additional training and support in order to provide more intensive care to children who may have complex mental health, behavioral, or medical needs.The program requires specially trained resource parents and professional and paraprofessional support. The ISFC program provides core services and supports to a child/youth in foster care. These core services may include, but are not limited to arranging access to mental health treatment, providing trauma informed care and providing transitional support from foster placement to permanent home placement.The goal is to ensure that the services needed are provided in a home-based family care setting or to prevent placement into, or assistance stepping down from, a Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP). Along with additional services and supports, the caregiver is paid the highest home-based foster care rate available.
eligibility:
An eligible child for ISFC is a child or nonminor dependent in foster
care who requires a higher level of care of supervision as determined by the Level of
Care Rate Determination Protocol (LOCP) - youth who score a five in either the Health or Behavioral Domains of the LOCP qualify for ISFC. The placing agency's Interagency Placement Committee can also approve a youth for ISFC.

name: Home Based IMC (EISFC or ISFC+)
description:
A program-specific or a child-specific rate for a county-designed Innovative Model of Care (IMC) providing an innovative program or model of care and services to support foster children and Non-Minor Dependents (NMDs) with complex needs unable to be met in existing Aid to Families with Dependent Children-Foster Care (AFDC-FC) programs or using alternative funding sources. For youth who have enhanced care, supervision, and service needs, not met by any other available placement/program, as a way to divert from residential care. Home-based IMC, sometimes called Enhanced ISFC (EISFC) or ISFC+, can be created as an individual model for the resource parent home (known as a professional parent model), or as an individual model per youth who needs placement. IMC gives counties and caregivers ability to be innovative in creating a set of services and supports tailored to the complex care youth. The plan is negotiated between the county and the potential caregiver. The IMC Rate is created in partnership with County or Tribe, the potential placement, and the CDSS Rate’s Oversight Unit based on the  needs and supports  being provided by the potential placement.

IMC could encompass innovative models across counties, including Two Family Homes, programs that utilize old MTFC/ITFC principles and programming, and partnerships with behavioral health, respite, and other providers.
eligibility:
Youth with complex care needs can be assessed for an IMC placement.
Caregivers who are able and willing to meet the needs of complex care youth, may apply to be an IMC home. 
Both child specific, and home/facility based IMC, require approval from CDSS.

using alternative funding sources. For youth who have enhanced care

name: Congregate Care IMC (STRTP of One or Two
description:
A program-specific or a child-specific rate for a county-designed Innovative Model of Care (IMC) providing an innovative program or model of care and services to support foster children and Non-Minor Dependents (NMDs) with complex needs unable to be met in existing Aid to Families with Dependent Children-Foster Care (AFDC-FC) programs or using alternative funding sources. Congregate care IMC can provide care and services for a child or NMD in foster care with complex needs who would not otherwise be successful if placed in an STRTP congregate care setting.  Congregate care based IMC, sometimes called an STRTP of One or STRTP of Two, can be created as a program model, or as an individual model per youth who needs placement. This IMC should seek to provide an innovative approach using, in new and original ways, intensive child-to-staff ratios, multi-systemic involvement, intensive clinical supports, intensive care coordination that is focused on a timely transition to a less restrictive setting, and utilize trauma-informed models, including intensive home-based services, wraparound services, and after care supports.
An STRTP of One or Two must comply with all the licensing and child welfare requirements that apply to all STRTPs. While an STRTP of One IMC may be either program-specific or child-specific, an STRTP of Two IMC is likely to be program-specific.  The IMC Rate is created in partnership with County or Tribe, the potential placement, and the CDSS Rate’s Oversight Unit based on the  needs and supports  being provided by the potential placement.
eligibility:
Youth with complex care needs can be assessed for an IMC placement.
Caregivers who are able and willing to meet the needs of complex care youth, may apply to be an IMC home. 
Both child specific, and home/facility based IMC, require approval from CDSS.
partners_involved:
CWS
Probation
County Mental Health Plan

name: STRTP
description:
An STRTP provides short-term intensive care and supervision, services and supports, treatment, and 24-hour care and supervision of children/youth and NMDs in a congregate care setting. 

An STRTP is intended to serve children/youth and NMDs who need a level of care and supervision that cannot be safely met in a family-based setting and who are not in need of inpatient services.
eligibility:
Youth with complex care needs not able to be met safely in a home-based placement, must have assessment and approval by the following three in order to be in an STRTP placement:
- Interagency Placement Committee (IPC)
- Qualified Individual (QI)
- Juvenile Court

To qualify for placement in an STRTP, the youth must meet all of Criteria One and at least one of Criteria Two as authorized by the IPC screening, as follows:

Criteria One (1):
- Inpatient care in a licensed health care facility is not required, and
- A determination has been made in conjunction with the Child and Family Team which indicates that the child/youth/NMD requires the level of services provided by an STRTP.

Criteria Two (2):
- The child/youth/NMD meets the medical necessity criteria for Medi-Cal Specialty Mental Health Services as provided by an STRTP, or
- The child/youth/NMD is assessed as Seriously Emotionally Disturbed, or
- A licensed mental health professional assessed the youth as requiring the level of services provided in an STRTP in order to meet the youth’s behavioral or therapeutic needs
partners_involved:
CWS
Probation
Regional Center
Behavioral Health
state_direction:
ACL 17-122
STRTP Interim Licensing Standards v5
ACL 21-114
ACL 21-113/BHIN 21-060
ACL 19-94

name: CTF
description: Community Treatment Facility (CTF):  A CTF provides 24-hour non-medical care and mental health treatment services to children in a secure environment, which are less restrictive than a hospital.  A facility's program design is subject to program standards developed and enforced by the State Department of Health Care Services (DHCS).
eligibility:
Youth with complex care needs not able to be met safely in a home-based placement or lower levels of congregate care, must have assessment and approval by the following three in order to be in an STRTP placement:
- Interagency Placement Committee (IPC)
- Qualified Individual (QI)
- Juvenile Court 
- Conservator (as applicable)

For the IPC screening to determine the appropriateness of treatment and placement in a CTF, the youth must be determined by a mental health care professional to be described as stated below:

The child/youth/NMD must meet one (1) or more of 1 a, or b, or c and items 2, 3, and 4 below.

1) The child/youth/NMD must have met the Seriously Emotionally Disturbed (SED) criteria as defined below.
a) Impairment in at least two (2) of the following areas: 
Self-Care
School Functioning
Family Relationships
Functioning in the community And either,
Risk of removal from home or has already been removed, or
The mental health disorder and impairments have been present for more than six (6) months, or are likely to continue for more than one (1) year without treatment.
b) The child/youth/NMD displays one (1) of the following:
Psychotic features
Risk of suicide
Risk of violence to other due to mental health disorder
c) The youth is a special education student that is determined to have an emotional disturbance.  This means a condition exhibiting one (1) or more of the following characteristics over a long period of time and to a degree that adversely affects a child's educational performance: 
An inability to learn that cannot be explained by intellectual, sensory, or health factors
An inability to build or maintain satisfactory interpersonal relationships with peers and teachers
Inappropriate types of behaviors or feelings under normal circumstances
A general pervasive mood of unhappiness or depression
A tendency to develop physical symptoms or fears associated with personal or school problems.
2) The youth may require a period of containment to participate in, and benefit from, mental health treatment, and the CTF program must be reasonably expected to improve the youth's mental health disorder.
3) Other, less restrictive interventions must have been attempted and proved insufficient; or, the youth is in an inpatient psychiatric hospital. This applies to youth's placed in and out of state.
This includes denial of admission into an STRTP through an IPC screening where it is determined the youth would benefit from a higher level of care.
This may include outpatient therapy, family counseling, case management, family preservation efforts, special education classes, or nonpublic schooling.
4) There must be consent for treatment/placement (by youth over age 18) or the youth must have a conservator appointed
partners_involved:
CWS
Probation
Regional Center
Behavioral Health

name: CCCPP
description:
The Children’s Crisis Continuum Pilot Program (CCCPP) provided funding for a select number of counties or regional collaboratives throughout California to implement a crisis continuum of care for foster youth with high acuity needs. The purpose of the Children’s Crisis Continuum is to fully integrate the system of care for foster youth enabling a seamless transition between service settings and to provide stabilization and treatment to foster youth with high acuity needs within the least restrictive setting possible. The program will have access to ISFC beds specifically selected at partnering FFAs to support youth with high level mental health or substance use disorder needs. Pilot youth may require a combination of highly individualized stabilization services, inpatient treatment, or intensive transition planning and aftercare services. 

Pilot funding can be used to support activities including but not limited to:
-Investment in infrastructure and start up behavioral health services and placements for foster youth including Intensive Services Foster Care (ISFC) homes, Children’s Crisis Residential Programs, (CCRPs), Crisis Stabilization Units (CSUs), and Psychiatric Health Facilities (PHFs).
- Specialized services and supports for foster youth such as child-specific recruitment, intensive family finding and engagement, respite care, and additional therapeutic foster care options.
eligibility:
Counties awarded a CCCPP grant:
- Fresno & Madera Counties
- Los Angeles County
- Monterey County
- Riverside & San Bernardino Counties
- San Diego County
- San Francisco, Contra Costa, Marin, Solano, and
Sonoma Counties
- San Luis Obispo County
- Stanislaus, Merced, and San Joaquin Counties

Counties select their own specific eligibility criteria as reviewed and accepted by CDSS at the time of grant awarding.

name: Transitioal Housing Program (THP) - NMD
description:
A placement program available to NMDs ages 18 up to 21. Offered by a licensed transitional housing placement provider (THPP) to provide safe housing for NMDs and assistance in developing the skills needed for transitioning to independent living with assistance from a case manager. 

The Transitional Housing Program (THP)-NMD provides current and former foster youth additional supports they need to successfully transition to independence while reducing the risks of homelessness, unemployment, and instability after foster care. By providing housing, life skills training, and guidance, the program helps Nonminor Dependents build a strong foundation for independent living and self-sufficiency. 

THP-NMD provides three types of supervised housing:
Single-Site Housing – Apartments or dorm-style housing where multiple NMDs live in the same building with onsite support staff.
Scattered-Site Housing – Individual apartments or shared housing located throughout the community, with regular case management visits.
Host Family Model – NMDs live with a caring adult mentor (host family) who provides support and guidance while maintaining independence.
eligibility:
To qualify for THP-NMD, youth must:
Be between 18 and 21 years old
Be in Extended Foster Care (EFC) under a court-ordered placement
Have a Transitional Independent Living Plan (TILP)
Be engaged in school, work, training, or treatment
Be willing to participate in program activities and case management.

name: FFA
description: A Foster Family Agency (FFA) is a public agency or private organization, organized and operated on a nonprofit basis. FFAs recruit, approve, provide training for, and provide support and services to Resource Families.  FFAs coordinate with county placing agencies to find homes for dependent children in need of care. All homes within an FFA must be RFA approved. Youth may be placed in an FFA RFA home if they can safely be maintained at a home-based level of care, just as in county-based RF homes. FFAs could have standard RFA home, or could have treatment homes that run ISFC and/or TFC programs for higher needs youth.
eligibility: Youth may be placed in a RF home when the youth's needs can be safely met by the caregiver, placing agency, and Child and Family Team - including both natural and formal supports.
county_restrictions: a RF home when the youth's needs can be safely met by the caregiver

name: Group Home
description:
Historical Background: Group homes provided the most restrictive out-of-home placement option for children in foster care. They provided a placement option for children with significant emotional or behavioral problems who require more restrictive environments. The licensed group home is defined as a facility of any capacity which provide 24-hour nonmedical care and supervision to children in a structured environment, with such services provided at least in part by staff employed by the licensee. Group homes run the gamut from large institutional type environments which provide an intense therapeutic setting, often called "residential treatment centers," to small home environments which incorporate a "house parent" model. As a result, group home placements provide various levels of structure, supervision and services.
Group homes may offer specific services targeted to a specific population of children or a range of services depending on the design of their program. These services include substance abuse, minor-parent (mothers and babies), infant programs, mental health treatment, vocational training, mental health day treatment, sex offenders, wards only, emancipation and reunification. Many programs provide more than one service and list their primary service function as reunification of children with the biological family. A high number also list their primary function as emancipation.
eligibility: Per WIC 17736(b), group homes are generally no longer allowable as a placement for children/youth in foster care, with the exception of licensed group homes that have been vendorized by a Regional Center to serve Regional Center clients.

name: Small Family Home (Non-Vendorized)
description:
A Small Family Home (SFH) is a for-profit licensed facility that provides 24-hour care for six or fewer children, often those with disabilities, requiring special care and supervision. Staff in the home may include the operator of the home, assistant caregivers, on-call assistants, and other providers. For SFH's not vendorized by Regional Center, Child Welfare must negotiate the services provided and rate paid for each placement. Services in a SFH may include:
Child activities
Participating with agencies and other responsible persons in planning for and providing the needs of the child.
Ensuring that the child is clean and providing the child with training in personal cleanliness and hygiene.
Protecting the child from home accidents.
Making provisions for the child to attend available community treatment or training programs when the child has needs which can be met by such programs.
Assisting the child in the development of goals and encouraging them to reach those goals.
Supervising the provision of basic services within the home.
Unless restricted by the case plan adopted by the court or other court order,  permit and facilitate connections between the child and the child’s family and non-relative extended family members. 
Provide access and information reagrding vocational and other postsecondary educational options.
eligibility: Small Family Homes are generally no longer allowable as a placement for children/youth in foster care, with the exception of licensed SFHs that have been vendorized by a Regional Center to serve Regional Center clients.

name: Supervised Independent Living Placement (SILP)
description: A SILP is a placement option for NMDs who are in Extended Foster Care (EFC). The SILP is intended to provide young adults with the opportunity for highly independent living experiences while receiving financial support along with the safety net of a SW caseworker to provide support and services for problems that arise. A SILP may be with parent or guardian from whom the youth was removed .
eligibility:
NMDs, including married NMDs, are responsible for finding their own SILP; however, the SILP must still be approved by the SW.

NMDs receiving a Dual Agency Rate are not appropriate for a SILP.

name: Day Treatment Intensive

May include contact with significant support persons or other collaterals if the purpose of their participation is to focus on the treatment of the beneficiary
Must have an established site but some components can be delivered off site
Some service components may be delivered through telehealth or telephone
Includes:
Assessment
Treatment Planning
Therapy
Psychosocial Rehabilitation

Meet Medical Necessity Criteria for SMHS for 21 and under

The goal of crisis intervention is to stabilize an immediate crisis within a community or clinical treatment setting
May include contact with significant support persons or other collaterals if the purpose of their participation is to focus on the treatment of the beneficiary

name: Community-Based Mobile Crisis Services
description:

Includes de-escalation and stabilization techniques that reduce the immediate risk and subsequent harm; and avoid unnecessary emergency department care, psychiatric inpatient hospitalizations, and law enforcement involvement
Includes warm handoffs to appropriate settings and providers when the beneficiary requires additional stabilization and/or treatment services with and referrals to appropriate health, social and other services and supports, as needed; and short-term follow up support to help ensure the crisis is resolved and the beneficiary is connected to ongoing care
May include contact with a family member(s) or other significant support colateral(s)
For children and youth, in particular, mobile crisis teams shall work extensively with parents, caretakers and guardians, as appropriate, and in a manner that is consistent with al federal and state laws related to minor consent, privacy and confidentiality
Mobile crisis services are provided by a multidisciplinary mobile crisis team at the location where the beneficiary a behavioral health crisis
24/7/365 access

name: PHP
description:
PHPs are a type of outpatient treatment that provides a more intensive level of care than traditional outpatient therapy, but less intense than inpatient treatment.
Participants attend the program for several hours a day, several days a week, and return home in the evenings.
They are designed for individuals who need a structured and intensive environment to manage their mental health or substance use challenges, but don't require around-the-clock care. 
Services may include:

Individualized treatment plans tailored to each client's needs.
Therapy groups, including cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT), social skills groups, and mindfulness groups.
Medication management and evaluation.
Group activities and experiential therapy.
Coping skills training.
Relapse prevention strategies.
Psychiatric assessment and evaluation.
Case management and discharge planning.
Vocational counseling.
Family therapy.
Educational support.
eligibility:
Enrolled in Medi-Cal 
People with moderate to severe symptoms of mental health disorders who need structured support to manage their conditions.

name: Vendored Small Family Homes
description:
A Small Family Home (SFH) is a licensed facility that provides 24-hour care for six or fewer children, often those with disabilities, requiring special care and supervision. Staff in the home may include the operator of the home, assistant caregivers, on-call assistants, and other providers. Services in a SFH include:
Child activities
Participating with agencies and other responsible persons in planning for and providing the needs of the child.
Ensuring that the child is clean and providing the child with training in personal cleanliness and hygiene.
Making provisions for the child to attend available community treatment or training programs when the child has needs which can be met by such programs.
Assisting the child in the development of goals and encouraging them to reach those goals.
Supervising the provision of basic services within the home.
Unless restricted by the case plan adopted by the court or other court order,  permit and facilitate connections between the child and the child’s family and non-relative extended family members. 
Provide access and information reagrding vocational and other postsecondary educational options.

The vendorization process allows regional centers to verify, prior to the provision of services to consumers, that an applicant meets all of the requirements and standards specified in regulations.
eligibility:
Youth ages 0-17 active to a regional center due to an identified disability who require special care and supervision due to their developmental, mental, or physical handicap.
Youth 18-19 who continue to be provided care and supervision by a caregiver in the home. 
Youth 18-22 who meet the definition for child with special healthcare needs
Placements in SFHs can be done by a regional center, a parent/guardian, or a child placing agency; with or without a court order.
The operator of the SFH is required to assess that they can meet the individual needs of the child and can still meet the needs of other children in the home, before accepting placement.
partners_involved: Vendored by Developmental Services, also utilized by Child Welfare for Dual Services youth.
